Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “We need you to lead the ceremony this year. It’s important for our family.” My heart thudded. I knew what it meant—standing before everyone, reciting prayers, making sure every ritual was perfect. It was my turn to uphold our traditions, to show respect for our ancestors. But as I glanced at the clock, I remembered my next fare was due in ten minutes. My cab was spotless, the seats freshly wiped, the air just right. My regulars expected nothing less; a single complaint could cost me my reputation, maybe even my job. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family needed me to honor our heritage, to be the daughter they could be proud of. My passengers needed me to be reliable, professional, always on time. I gripped the steering wheel, torn between the pull of home and the demands of the road, not knowing which direction to turn.
